p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Andrew Wallace ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
PARLIAMENTARY OFFICE HOLDERS
Speaker

The SPEAKER (10:01): I report that I presented myself to His Excellency the Governor-General as the choice of the House as its Speaker and that His Excellency was kind enough to congratulate me. His Excellency also presented to me an authority to administer members the oath or affirmation of allegiance. I now lay the authority on the table.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:02): I present the 34th report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th Parliament, together with 21 petitions and 32 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.
PETITIONS
Presentation
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:02): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, and in accordance with standing order 207, I present the following petitions:
COVID-19: Vaccination
There is No evidence that Healthy children are susceptible to the Sars Covid 19 Virus.
The risk of using a Novel Vaccine with No long term history of Safety or Efficacy would be irresponsible.
We therefore ask the House to Not pursue the use of such vaccines on our children 5 to 11 years old.
from 30,932 citizens (Petition No. EN3496)
COVID-19: Vaccination

Many developing nations are suffering from the pandemic due to limited access to effective vaccines, while Australians enjoy access to AstraZeneca, Pfizer and Moderna Vaccines. As preference has been given to continuation of MRNA variants due to lesser side effects, production of AstraZeneca is seemingly being abandoned without thought for other nations in dire need of this resource. Given Australia rightfully dedicated resources to helping these developing nations, and is already set up and producing these AstraZeneca vaccines, it only makes sense to continue production and distribution of the AZ vaccine to developing countries in need. It should be noted that still to this day, countries like Thailand and other south East Asian nations predominantly have access only to the less effective and problematic chinese vaccines such as Sinovac and Sinopharm. Let's do the right thing and get these quality AstraZeneca supplies which are more cost effective and easily trassportable to nations who desperately need them as soon as possible.

We therefore ask the House to review policy and take action to ensure AstraZeneca Vaccine production is continued and Australian resources are used effectively to support our neighbours and developing nations in their access to quality and effective Covid 19 vaccines.
from 33 citizens (Petition No. EN3497)
Housing Affordability

As a Property Manager of multiple NRAS Properties and General Tenancy properties, I am on the ground and have first hand knowledge of the benefits of 'affordable housing'. NRAS houses are in the top percentage of the best maintained properties in our offices property portfolio. This is clear evidence that, not only are NRAS houses going to people at risk of homelessness due to low income, the houses are going to people who show sincere appreciation of the affordable housing by maintaining them in excellent condition. Rent payments are also in the top percentage with minimum to no rent arrears with NRAS tenants. NRAS housing has provided affordable housing to the elderly and to those people with a disability. It has provided them with a home and some independence. The quality of NRAS Housing has been outstanding and has offered housing to those deserving of a hand up and those who just needed a bit of help to prevent them from becoming homeless. NRAS Housing has filled a huge gap in Australian housing needs, previously not catered to. The ending of NRAS will recreate the huge gap in everyday Australians housing needs and will result in excessive stress being for residents who will be displaced and at risk of homelessness when NRAS ends.
We therefore ask the House to consider increasing Government Rent Assistance for ex-NRAS housing residents when the homes that they reside in have their NRAS classification ended.
from 140 citizens (Petition No. EN3502)
Waste Management and Recycling

The replacements are terrible especially the paper straws the go all soft and soggy and wooden cutlery they make the food taste horrible also the paying for bags at store are ridicules they should be free and you cant use them for rubbish bags.
We therefore ask the House to stop the banning of plastic products.
from 8 citizens (Petition No. EN3503)
Animal Welfare

While cosmetic companies don't test their products on animals here in Australia, many well-known brands do test their products or ingredients on animals overseas, and those products end up on Australian shelves.
An estimated 27,000 live rabbits, mice, rats are still being used for cosmetics testing across the world. Each animal experiences pain and distress. Most will be killed after the experiment.
There are already more than 20,000 chemical ingredients already considered safe and available to producers of cosmetics products, so there's no excuse for any more animals to suffer.

In 2019, the Australian Government passed legislation that aimed to end animal testing for new cosmetic ingredients. However, the legislation only applies to chemicals used solely for cosmetic purposes. This means that chemical ingredients used in cosmetics, and for some other purpose like a household cleaning product, can still be tested on animals.
This loophole must be closed to ensure that no new ingredients that are used in cosmetic products can be tested on animals.
We therefore ask the House to end animal testing for ALL chemicals in Australia.
from 210 citizens (Petition No. EN3507)
Australian Defence Force

As the policy is per currently implemented, the Australian Defence Force's medical requirement has placed many young Australians out of their ambitious goals of serving their nation despite administrative roles that are not involved in putting themselves in the front line.

As a comparison, the Israel Defence Force enlist deaf soldiers and officers to fit into the roles of translators for example hence ADF's enlisting requirement should solely depend more on the person's competency and capabilities over the such conditions that may not put affect their chosen role but benefit the defence.

If the Israel Defence Force are able to have deaf soldiers in its' military force, why can't the Australian Defence Force? Linked to the first sentence, many Australians with pre-existing medical conditions are disqualified as they're unable or may be affect their workplace safety.

We therefore ask the House to implement or to possibly review a new policy for Australian Defence Force candidates with pre-existing medical conditions (such as deafness) to appeal and possibly make it through the process of enlisting into the Australian Defence Force.
from 7 citizens (Petition No. EN3509)
First Nations People

In February 2020 the high court handed down a ruling in its a constitutional ruling in the case of Brendan Thoms and Daniel Love. This is in the case of there aboriginality was accepted by first nations people and they have first nations ancestors this is accepted by the first nations people. Now a few conservative politicians are trying to have this overturned. We are asking for aboriginal affairs minister ken wyatt to have this brought to indigenous Australians Attention.Im asking for this decision from the high court to stay as it is as it undermines the previous high court ruling and undermines the question of Aboriginal rights and the elders in the community.@kristina keaneally @warrenmundine
We therefore ask the House to (Abandon) the push to have the high court ruling overturned.

February 2020 this ruling reinforces the rights of aboriginals and there future children who could possibly be born overseas it is unsafe to deport aboriginal Australians or anyone who has aboriginal ancestry. This undermining the rights of Aboriginals and the first nations people it is Unethical and Unconstitutional.
from 30 citizens (Petition No. EN3510)
Assange, Mr Julian
Julian Assange's health and life are in danger. He is the subject of extreme injustice.

We therefore ask the House to make a simple support statement for Julian Assange. I wish it to tell the US Administration to drop the charges against Julian Assange, to stop his extradition to the US and for the Australian government to bring him home.
His health and life depend upon it.
from 686 citizens (Petition No. EN3512)
Naloxone

The current requirements for naloxone to be purchased and prescribed currently is difficult for Non users of opiates and in some cases expensive causing people to AVOID training and gain access to this life saving medication that has shown to be affective and not a drug at risk of abuse.

We therefore ask the House to allow ALL doctors prescribe Naloxone to people that are friends, family or a member of the public without being a user them selves also offer a "Take home" program Australia wide for people that have Low or No income.
from 8 citizens (Petition No. EN3513)
Health Care

Recent times has exposed Government's real influence in our Doctors Office and has uncovered medical professionals are being coerced or threatened with investigation or stricken of the registrar for practicing good medicine for their patients when in contradiction to the Government's changing and confusing narrative.

The ability for Government to drive an agenda by influencing treatment for the masses is not just disturbing but is too great a temptation for being hijacked, open to manipulation and also violates the Australian Constitution. These are trusted positions involving private consultation on very personal issues. Leave the medical professionals to practice good medicine not politics, and for politicians to stop practicing medicine.

We therefore ask the House to keep out the political influence of APHRA, TGA and in general any Government department regardless of title at the time, to stay out of our Doctors Office by running a Constitutional lens over Government policy. To allow under no-duress, Medical Professionals to diagnose and treat, and to avoid the potential malpractice of ill-informed, narrative changing, agenda driven, self-serving politician/s as they can not be stricken of the registrar and are not accountable.
from 677 citizens (Petition No. EN3515)
Broadband

NBN has fallen short of expectations in nearly ever sense. $5 billion over budget for a disappointing rollout that has left countless people disappointed. Slow speeds, connection dropping out and inaccurate advertising are sights all Australians are too familiar with

During the pandemic when working and studying from home was vital in containing cases, countless Australians found themselves struggling to do basic tasks on the internet. Even prior to the lockdowns, accessing the internet during off peak periods yielded the same results. NBN advertising fast speeds yet countless people have failed to see numbers even a fraction of the promised speed.

Australia is a country that is isolated from most of the world, we depend on access to a stable internet connection to conduct both business, and connect with those from around the world. As time passes, we collectively have shifted away from paper documents and now rely on cloud services. These allow for people to access and send things on the go, more convenient now than ever. Yet we may not have learnt from our mistakes and end up in the same predicament there.

It is essential that the government sees to it that we aren't the face of a technological dark age in the future. We cannot ignore the importance of the internet, Australia has the potential to be the forefront of internet infrastructure.
We therefore ask the House to develop a cohesive plan to rework current infrastructure, and ensure that all properties will have the opportunity to access fast connections.
from 35 citizens (Petition No. EN3518)
Climate Change

Politicians have come to believe that human produced CO2 is destroying the environment, while the scientific evidence that it is an essential trace gas, critical to all life, and greening of the planet, is the reality, and that nature produces 97% of all CO2. Politicians must stop promoting fraud, which is purely part of the agenda for the meger wealthy elites to own and control everything, including to totally control our governments, using these globalist lies and agendas, such as the lies of global warming due to human activity.
We therefore ask the House to cease and decist in demonising CO2 produced by human activity, and refuse to take part in the madness of "net zero".
from 67 citizens (Petition No. EN3519)
Electoral Roll
Fraud exist throughout society and 'we the people' believe that each individual should have their 'rightful' claim to vote protected.

We formally identify ourselves via photo identification in many places in our community and when using services, we would like this formal identification process extended to electoral polling to ensure our voters rights are protected from fraudsters.

We therefore ask the House to act on the peoples request; We the people put forward that there be changes made to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 specifically section 229 to include that the presiding officer or polling official should validate the voter eligibility to vote by the sighting of the claimants formal identification (licence, passport or 18-plus card). Those that wish to postal vote or absentee vote should have their ballot paper and photo identification witnessed and recorded by a JP or similar.
Only after the voters photo identification has been sighted by a presiding officer or witnessed that the vote/voter may be recorded (section 232).
from 67 citizens (Petition No. EN3527)
Autism

The Helping Children With Autism Scheme is inherently biased against girls. The scheme provides support to young boys or girls with extreme symptoms. However studies show that most girls and women, don't realise they are autistic/aren't able to be diagnosed until their late teens and 20s. This means that if someone present with symptoms after 13, they will have to pay $2,500 for a diagnosis or go through life never being diagnosed
We therefore ask the House to extend the scheme to youth ages up to 25 years old, to allow all people equal chance to be diagnosed.
from 181 citizens (Petition No. EN3528)
Media

Under the News Media Bargaining Code Google and Facebook have struck deals with a small number of media outlets. However, they have refused to negotiate with the majority of Australian news providers—including a range of high-quality outlets that meet the criteria set out in the Code. By publishing public interest journalism these providers fight misinformation and inject expertise into the media ecosystem. Only designation by the Treasurer can bring Facebook to the negotiation table.

We therefore ask the House to request that Treasurer Josh Frydenberg "designate" Google and Facebook under the News Media Bargaining Code to force Google and Facebook to negotiate payment for all publishers who genuinely serve the public interest.
from 1,224 citizens (Petition No. EN3530)
COVID-19: Vaccination

As a no fault indemnity scheme has recently been established to compensate people who have severe reactions to COVID-19 vaccines, we call on the Australian government to extend the scheme to those who have (and have previously had) severe reactions to other TGA approved vaccines.

Though vaccines are by and large effective and safe, severe reactions such as anaphylaxis and auto-immune responses do occur and victims of such rare adverse reactions are often left with lifelong ailments that prevent them from living a normal life. We have a great healthcare system in Australia but Medicare and the NDIS simply can't replace years, even decades of lost earnings and the ability to pay off a mortgage, nor the emotional and physical toll of living with a permanent disability or chronic illness.

The RACGP amongst others has advocated for such a scheme and it is time every citizen of Australia be entitled to the same simplified means of obtaining compensation regardless of which vaccine caused them injury. It is incumbent upon the Australian government to recognise the small amount of people who have paid an enormous price for doing their bit for the benefit of all Australians and compensate them accordingly.
We therefore ask the House to introduce a national compensation scheme covering historical and future severe adverse reactions to all TGA approved vaccines.
from 571 citizens (Petition No. EN3532)
Employment

On the day of writing, 20/10/2021, Woolworths recalled scissors and knives from shelves in response to a customer stabbing. Earlier this week, Woolworths paid a grieving family $6000 after their son took his life; a result of workplace entrapment. This act alone demonstrates Woolworths will sacrifice tens of thousands in sales to appear like they care for customers, but value their employees at $6000.

Woolworths, Coles, McDonalds and other giants that employ low-skilled workers operate with a systemic culture of managerial abuse seen through budget cuts, gaslighting and coercion. Budget cuts are especially damaging to employees; not only giving the poorest workers unreliable income but forcing salaried managers to work hours of overtime with no extra pay to achieve the work required. Some managers even resort to narcotics to maintain an alert state.

Woolworths uses an "O.R.%" to calculate wages; hours needed vs hours budgeted. Departments are expected to operate at above 100%. A department may receive at 28hr work load that day, but only be budgeted 20hrs to complete the work. As a result, shortcuts are taken and substance abuse begins to frantically meet those hours until the budgets are cut again.
We therefore ask the House to support the establishment of such a Royal Commission into Retail and Fast Food conditions and culture.
from 1,213 citizens (Petition No. EN3533)
Australian Broadcasting Corporation
ABC paid for by the Australian people are purposefully being deceived through Reporting Omissions, potentially seen as Sedition and least and at worst Treason.
QUESTIONS for ITA: Ita Clare Buttrose and Board
- Why is ABC concealing the fact surrounding adverse reactions to injections?
- Why is ABC concealing the real reason for the increasing numbers of suicides?
- Why is ABC concealing unlawful basis to lockdowns?
- Why is ABC concealing unjustified police brutality?
- Why is ABC concealing coercion by GOVT of disadvantaged groups?
- Why is the ABC concealing the destruction of the people's businesses?
- Why is ABC concealing the connection between big pharma and WHO CDC?
- Why is ABC concealing Pedophilia and protecting Pedophiles?

We therefore ask the House to press upon the ABC, Ita Clare Buttrose and Board to answer these questions about these Reporting Omissions that can be seen as an agenda to influence and manipulate the Australian People and Democracy.
from 372 citizens (Petition No. EN3534)
Australian Federal Police

With clear over reach of police with in Victoria and New South Wales as well as a history of corruption, it is clear there needs to be a chain of command in place that allows for the Australian Federal Police to have the powers to investigate for the purpose of preventing and or stopping corruption of state/territory police. This over reach seems to most recently be by questionable mp's who are currently under investigation who have in recent times used their police force as a private militia. Such over reach is a violation of rights by the states and is time for protection from such actions at a federal level.
Such actions have brought the country to the world stage for the wrong reasons.

Giving AFP special powers to police the police will stop any politician or non elected official as appointed by a political "friend" from utilizing members who are bound by their role in law enforcement.
Several members have recently resigned due to these mandates and spoken out. This is unfair for them and places many at risk from public outcry as well as diminishing faith in the police.
We therefore ask the House to pass a bill to allow the AFP special powers to investigate, charge and bring order to any state or territory that is over stepping boundaries.
To maintain a level of freedom from corruption equal to all Australians that will protect our democratic way of life
from 332 citizens (Petition No. EN3535)
Afghanistan

Students of St John Fisher and St Patrick's Colleges in Brisbane, as future leaders of Australia, recognise and appreciate the Government's existing efforts in Afghanistan, however ask that we urgently intensify these actions. Children have no access to education; their daily life is precarious. We must set an example to other nations by increasing our response.

Below are five vital actions (based on the Refugee Council of Australia's petition), that we believe the minister for Immigration can urge the Australian Government to take to respond to the crisis in Afghanistan): 1. Keep our borders open for people trying to flee persecution in Afghanistan; 2. Offer additional refugee resettlement places for Afghan refugees immediately. Just as Canada has already announced its commitment of 20,000 additional places for Afghan refugees, Australia could match this offer and demonstrate that we, as a country, are ready to share this responsibility; 3. Ensure that those whose asylum claims have been previously rejected are supported if making new claims based on the changed circumstances in Afghanistan. 4. Extend permanent protection to any an all Afghans on temporary protection visas, recognising they are unlikely to return safely to Afghanistan for many years to come. This will give people the assurance that they can continue to live in Australia without the constant fear of forced return. 5. Assist Afghan Australians with urgent family reunion applications, particularly for those family members being targeted by the Taliban because of their links to western nations.
from 566 citizens (Petition No. PN0523)
Kashmir

With respect to a peaceful protest at Kangaroo Point Cliffs Park in Brisbane on 28th of August 2021 to show solidarity with Kashmiris on the second anniversary of the illegal annexation of the Indian Occupied Kashmir which occurred on 5th of August 2019 by the current Indian Government, this petition from the citizens of Australia draws the attention to the House of Representatives. The Australian and South East Asian community strongly condemns this unconstitutional step taken by the Indian Government against the UN resolution and its ongoing human rights violations against Kashmiris and therefore, would like to draw the attention of the Australian Government towards this important matter. Please refer attached file for signatures of all petitioners.

We request the House to play its role by diplomatically addressing this issue at the right forums to ensure that the right of self-determination is given to the people of Kashmir as per the UN resolutions and the human rights violations under the current siege post illegal annexation of IOK are properly scanned and investigated on routine basis.
from 75 citizens (Petition No. PN0524)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:02): I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Department of Veterans' Affairs
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021 to the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon Darren Chester MP, regarding petition number EN2442. The petition relates to increasing Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) Delegate numbers by 50 per cent in the Australian Government's financial budget 2021/2022 and to continue resourcing for permanent Delegates to be employed within DVA. As this matter now falls within my portfolio responsibilities your letter has been passed to me for response.

I acknowledge there are concerns around DVA staffing and its impact on managing or completing the complexity of existing claims or requesting services resulting in significant backlogs in some claims processing types.

In the May 2021 Budget, the Australian Government provided an additional $98.5 million over the next two financial years to the claims processing function. This investment builds on prior additional funding of over $54 million over the last two years.

This continued investment in veterans will provide DVA with a significant increase to its staffing allocation to address the backlog of claims and manage the increased workload. These combined initiatives will see an increase to DVA's staffing by more than 440 positions, a significant number of those being dedicated to addressing the claims backlog.

Claim volumes have more than doubled over the last two years to more than 121,000 in 2019-20. This increase in claims is largely being driven by the success of initiatives like the Veteran Centric Reform Program, with veterans lodging claims closer to the time of injury and a better knowledge throughout the veteran community of entitlements.

Compensation claims processing performance continues to improve. The number of claims determined has increased by around 15 per cent from 2018-19 to 2019-20. However, the scale of the increase in claims being submitted to DVA has resulted in some veterans waiting longer for a determination.

DVA processes every claim individually, based on individual circumstance and available evidence. To make a thorough evidence-based decision, DVA often requires information from third parties (for example, treating doctors). The length of time taken to receive this information is often outside of DVA's control and can impact processing times.

I acknowledge extended processing times may have a detrimental impact on veteran health. That is why additional measures have been taken to ensure claims are triaged and veterans and their families can access support while claims are determined. These measures include:

working closely with the Department of Defence to identify members who are transitioning, in particular those being medically discharged, to prioritise their claims to support continuity of health services;
upfront access to mental health care and access to medical treatment for a range of common conditions;
interim financial support for mental health claims via the Veteran Payment;
interim payments for Permanent Impairment cases;
addressing complexities of dual or tri Act eligibility by establishing a dedicated team with trained, experienced delegates to process the oldest tri Act claims; and
further technological enhancements to make the claim process simpler and easier for veterans and their families.

In addition, claims are screened upon receipt. If a veteran is experiencing significant life events such as homelessness (or being at the risk of), a terminal illness, life threatening condition(s) and/or extended financial hardship, their claims are prioritised. DVA encourages anyone in these circumstances to make contact immediately to access support. Anyone who has concerns about the timeliness of their claim, or feel that their circumstances warrant prioritisation, should call DVA on 1800 VETERAN (1800 838 372).
DVA is also improving its communication with veterans by:
• establishing a claims support team to assist with faster processing of backlog cases;
• sending SMS messages at one, two and three months after a claim has been lodged;
• conducting welfare checks and providing additional support for veterans who do not respond during the claims process;
• establishing an advanced phone service for outbound calls to veterans through the Veterans Access Network; and
• making calls, and sending follow-up emails from delegates to veterans advising when their claims are assigned.

Free and confidential counselling and support to service and ex-service men and women, as well as their partners and children is also available from Open Arms—Veterans & Families Counselling (Open Arms). Open Arms can be contacted 24/7 on 1800 011 046. More information can also be found at www.openarms.gov.au.

The measures taken by the Australian Government to improve OVA claim processing capacity coupled with substantial support arrangements for those who may be experiencing delays and simplifying arrangements, is improving the overall claiming experience for the vast majority of veterans and their families.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Personnel, Mr Gee
Broadband
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email, dated 9 August 2021, on behalf of the Petitions Committee concerning Petition EN2688. The petition requests that I direct the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) to match Starlink's licence area to the NBN satellite area.

The Morrison Government's policy is that all people in Australia should be able to access modern telecommunications services regardless of where they live. NBN satellite and fixed wireless services are available in locations that are technically and financially challenging to deploy fibre infrastructure. The Government welcomes competition to the NBN, including from Starlink.

The Government has placed no restrictions on where Starlink may be licensed to operate its satellite service. It was a commercial decision of Starlink to take out licences for its beta service only for the remote and low density areas of Australia. Spacex had noted concerns about the price of spectrum as part of ACMA's spectrum pricing review, however I understand that Starlink may need to deploy more satellites and ground stations before adding customers in additional areas.

Recently ACMA implemented the outcomes of the pricing review, which saw a 90% reduction in the price for spectrum in the band used by Starlink. Starlink applied to ACMA for an Australia-wide apparatus licence which ACMA issued on 16 July 2021. Prospective customers should use the address checker on the Starlink website to find when their location will be served.
I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Australian Broadcasting Corporation
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 9 August 2021, concerning petition number EN2744, concerning the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC)'s editorial standards.

I have certainly been left in no doubt that the petitioners regard the ABC's editorial output as lacking in journalistic impartiality and balance. It is very important that the broadcaster's news and current affairs coverage meets the standards which Parliament, on behalf of all Australians, requires of it.
Even though the Morrison Government provides an overall level of funding to the ABC, the broadcaster has content and editorial independence.
Parliament has guaranteed this independence so the broadcaster's decisions are free from political interference.
Under this arrangement, the manner in which the ABC presents its programming is a matter for the ABC Board and executive.

Although editorially independent, the ABC Board is required to develop a Code of Practice relating to programming matters and to lodge this code with the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA).
In addition, the broadcaster is accountable to the Parliament through annual reports, corporate plans, financial and performance audits, and appearances before Parliamentary Committees.
I continue to maintain regular contact with the ABC Board to encourage them to maintain the broadcaster's adherence to its Charter, so it can provide useful and informative services.

I encourage concerned members of the public to actively engage with the ABC. Direct contact is the best way to guarantee that the ABC is made aware of the public's concerns and is given the opportunity to respond.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Afghanistan
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for forwarding me a copy of a petition EN2764 on behalf of the Petitions Committee under Standing Order 209(a) and (b) on 9 August 2021. In response to the petition, may I provide you with the following update on the Australian Government's continuing humanitarian efforts in response to the changing security circumstances in Afghanistan.

As you know, the Government has ceased its evacuation operations at Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul. The Government made every effort we could to get everyone out of Kabul, with our top priority being to evacuate Australians, visa holders and former locally engaged employees. The Government remains in close contact with our international partners and those in the region and we continue to monitor the situation in Afghanistan closely, and we urge all people remaining in Afghanistan to prioritise their safety. The situation remains highly volatile and travel throughout Afghanistan is extremely dangerous. The Government expects the Taliban to uphold its undertaking's to allow Australians and Afghan visa holders to depart Afghanistan safely if they wish to do so. However, people remaining in Afghanistan need to carefully consider the risks should they attempt to leave by any route.

Since 2013, more than 2,000 Afghan Locally Engaged Employees (LEEs) and their families at risk of harm due to their employment supporting Australia in Afghanistan have been resettled in Australia. This includes over 780 LEEs who have arrived in Australia since January 2021. Visa grants under the LEE program in 2020-21 were the highest since 2013-14. Afghan LEEs and their immediate family members with valid Australian visas are automatically exempt from Australia's travel restrictions. People who have applied for, and not met the threshold for Afghan LEE certification but have a connection with Australia, or are extended family members of Afghan LEE settled in Australia, are automatically being prioritised for consideration under Australia's Humanitarian Program. Those that have been certified as LEE but who have not yet lodged a visa application are encouraged to do so as soon as possible.

Those Afghans who have been granted visas and are still in Afghanistan will be contacted over the coming weeks by the Department of Home Affairs about what to do when it is safe. These visas will be honoured, including where possible with assistance to travel to Australia. People in this group who have not yet been contacted by the Department can contact the nearest Australian immigration office outside Australia.

The Government is working to ensure that visa options continue to be available to Afghan nationals, both within Afghanistan and for those displaced from their home country, through Australia's long-standing Humanitarian and Migration Programs. The most appropriate visa pathway will depend on the individual circumstances of each case. In some cases, people have pending partner applications that will be finalised, others may be processed into the Humanitarian program.

We encourage people in Afghanistan who don't have a visa, and would like to seek Australia's protection, to apply under our Humanitarian program. Afghan nationals are being prioritised for processing with an initial 3,000 humanitarian places allocated to them within Australia's 13,750 annual program. The Government anticipates this initial allocation will increase further over the course of 2021-22. Particular priority will be given to persecuted minorities, women and children and those who have links to Australia. Applicants must meet the visa criteria and satisfy public interest criteria for character, security and health. The Government will also continue to utilise our close working relationship with the United Nations High Commission for Refugees to identify those Afghans most in need.

I acknowledge this is a distressing time for so many people, including our Australian Afghan community, and we will do all we can to continue to assist those through our ongoing humanitarian efforts. The Government is working with Afghan community leaders in Australia, and leading refugee advocates and service providers to welcome people from Afghanistan to Australia and support their settlement. The Commonwealth Coordinator-General for Migrant Services, Alison Larkins, and expert in refugee settlement, Paris Aristotle AO, are leading an advisory panel to inform the Government's efforts to settle and integrate Afghan humanitarian entrants in Australia. The advisory panel includes Afghan community leaders and experts in migrant settlement and integration.

I also acknowledge that our veteran community may be affected by the situation in Afghanistan and am advised that the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) has reached out to the families of the 41 Defence personnel who tragically lost their lives in Afghanistan, as well as around 600 veterans and families identified as particularly vulnerable. Around 320,000 SMS messages were also sent to DVA clients to ensure they were aware of the support available to them and how to access it, if they needed it. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon Andrew Gee MP, has also encouraged Australians to connect with a veteran in recognition that, as a nation, we must all play our part in ensuring our veterans and their families are supported.

DVA continues to implement a communications and stakeholder engagement plan,, working with the media and ex-service organisations, to reinforce the message that 'support is available' to any veteran or their family if they need it, as well as engaging with the education sector to ensure the children of our veterans have appropriate support. These messages will remain particularly important as we commemorate the 20th anniversary of September 11 and the commencement of Australia's involvement in the war. I encourage you to promote the services of both DVA and Open Arms - Veterans & Families Counselling to any Australian Defence Force member, veteran or their family who may need some additional assistance.
I have copied this letter to the Hon Andrew Gee MP.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of those more than one thousand Australians who have supported this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Asylum Seekers
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021 enclosing petition EN2789 that has 107 signatures. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

For privacy reasons it would be inappropriate for me to go into detail about individual cases, however, I trust the following information regarding illegal arrivals to Australia will assist the petitioner.

Australia is committed to its international obligations set out in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol and other international human rights conventions to which it is a party. Australia does not return individuals to situations where they face persecution or a real risk of torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, arbitrary deprivation of life or the application of the death penalty.

Individuals who arrive lawfully in Australia seeking asylum, who are found to engage Australia's non-refoulement (non-return) obligations may be granted permanent protection, subject to fulfilling relevant visa criteria and the health, character and security requirements that apply to all Australian visas.

However, unlawful arrivals who engage Australia's protection obligations are only eligible for temporary protection. This upholds the Australian Government's commitment to process and recognise the protection claims of people who have arrived illegally, while at the same time guaranteeing that people-smugglers do not have a 'permanent Protection visa product' to sell.
The success of Australia's border protection policies enables the Government to make a generous contribution to addressing global humanitarian crises through our Humanitarian Program.
Thank you for brining petition EN2789 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Japan
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 09 August 2021, regarding petition EN2796 and joint custody arrangements in Japan.

The Australian Government is concerned about the number of Australian-Japanese children subject to parental abduction and custody disputes in Japan. We are aware of disputes where non-custodial parents in Japan have been unable to exercise their parental rights. These are matters for the Japanese courts. However, we consider it important that children at the centre of parental conflict are able to maintain links with both parents, and extended family.

The Australian Government continues to make representations to Japanese authorities to encourage Japan to find a solution acceptable to all and respectful of the best interests of the children. I have raised our concerns on this issue directly with my counterpart.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) is actively engaged on these issues working to improve access for Australian parents, making representations directly to the Japanese Government, and engaging with our likeminded partners on approaches. Our Embassy in Tokyo continues to provide consular support to affected parents in accordance with the Consular Services Charter.
DFAT officials will continue to engage Australian parents on these issues and our advocacy to ensure affected Australians are kept appraised of developments.

Parents of Australian children can seek consular assistance in regard to child custody issues from the Department's Consular and Crisis Management Division at centre.conops@dfat.gov.au or on 1300 555 135.

Parents whose children have been wrongfully removed from Australia, or wrongfully retained in Japan, along with parents in Australia who wish to enforce their rights of access to their children in Japan may be eligible to make an application under the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (Hague Convention).
Information about the Hague Convention can be found here:

https://www.ag.gov.au/families-and-marriage/families/international-family-law-and-children. The Australian Central Authority in the Attorney-General's Department can be contacted at australiancentralauthority@ag.gov.au.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
International Relations
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 23 August 2021 concerning Petition EN2804 to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Marise Payne. Your correspondence was referred to me on 3 September 2021, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

I note that the Department of Defence does fund a number of research grants and provides support to a number of thinks tanks. The Department of Defence complies with the Commonwealth Grants Rules and Guidelines 2017 and other governance measures. The think tanks involved have also demonstrated their commitment to transparency by publicly registering their activities.

On 17 August 2021, the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee, reported on its recent inquiry into funding for public research into foreign policy issues. In its submission to the inquiry, the Department of Defence highlighted the grant funding provided to support independent research, events, and activities that contribute to Australia's strategic debate and provide contestability to Defence's strategic policy advice. In support of these objectives, Defence runs a competitive grants program (the Strategic Policy Grants Program) which funds academic institutions and think tanks to address Australian defence and security priority policy topics. The details of individual grants are available through the Australian Government's GrantConnect website at:
https://www.arc.gov.au/grants/grantconnect-australian-governments-grant-information-system.

In addition to the Strategic Policy Grants Program, Defence provides grant funding to think tanks including the Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI) and the American Australian Association (to fund the United States Studies Centre and Perth USAsia Centre) to foster and deepen strategic policy discourse, debate and research of value to the Government, Department of Defence and wider Australian public.

While ASPI is a Commonwealth company, it is independent from Government and is governed by a charter to maintain that independence, including a non-partisan board. The United States Studies Centre, Perth USAsia Centre and ASPI also disclose funding through annual reporting and their websites.

The United States Studies Centre, Perth USAsia Centre and ASPI are all registered under the Foreign Influence Transparency Scheme (FITS) which is administered by the Attorney General's Department. The FITS provides the public with visibility of the nature, level and extent of foreign influence on Australia's political and governmental processes. It requires people and organisations who undertake certain activities to influence Australia's government and political processes on behalf of foreign principals to register these details on a public register.

More broadly the Government takes the threat of foreign interference very seriously. In addition to establishment of the policy-focussed Counter Foreign Interference Coordination Centre in my Department, the Government has also established an operational Counter Foreign Interference Taskforce charged with investigating allegations of foreign interference in Australia.

Working together, The FITS, the Counter Foreign Interference Coordination Centre and the Counter Foreign Interference Taskforce support a range of other legislative, regulatory and private sector frameworks that the Government has in place to promote the transparency and good governance that helps protect our free and open democracy.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2804 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Skilled Migration Program

Thank you for your correspondence of 23 August 2021 to the Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Karen Andrews MP, enclosing Petition EN2820 with 14 signatures, regarding language testing requirements for skilled migrants. Your correspondence has been referred to me, as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities as Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs. The Australian Government remains committed to using English language requirements in migration legislation as a means to effectively manage immigration risk and ensure visa holders are able to fully participate in the Australian community. Allowing certain applicants to provide a test score from one of the English language tests prescribed in migration law for visa purposes is reliable way for the Department of Home Affairs to assess an applicant's English language proficiency.

English language visa requirements are regularly reviewed by the Department to ensure they are fit-for-purpose. The issues raised in this petition will be taken into consideration as part of this ongoing process.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2820 to my attention.

Myanmar
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 30 August 2021, regarding the petition to officially meet with the National Unity Government (petition number EN2833).

The Australian Government remains gravely concerned about the situation in Myanmar and condemns the violence being perpetrated by the military regime against its people. We continue to call on the regime to immediately cease violence, release those detained arbitrarily, engage in dialogue, and return Myanmar to the path of democratic transition.

The Australian Government recognises states, not governments. I appreciate the importance of hearing from and understanding the voices and stakeholders for democracy in Myanmar. National Missing Persons Week
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 23 August 2021 enclosing Petition EN2862, from the Missing Persons Advocacy Network. This petition requests the Australian Government to officially recognise National Missing Persons Week. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Government recognises the importance of missing persons in Australia and is committed to supporting the agencies and networks, including the Missing Persons Advocacy Network, that endeavour to find and return missing persons to their loved ones.

The Government is proud to recognise and support National Missing Persons Week in a number of ways. Primarily, the Government raises community awareness by coordinating the annual police campaign through the Australian Federal Police National Missing Persons Coordination Centre. The Government also publicly acknowledges and supports similar annual campaigns and initiatives coordinated by the National Missing, Persons Coordination Centre, including International Missing Children's Day and the National Missing Persons Hackathon.

The proclamation of 'days of national observance' by the Governor-General, is one of a number of ways to promote the observation of days of celebration or commemoration. However, national days and weeks of observance, including National Missing Persons Week, may be observed without a proclamation or intervention by Government. A number of days throughout the year have gained community acceptance without Government involvement, such as Mother's Day and Red Nose Day. A proclamation by the Governor-General is not necessary for the Government to continue to raise awareness for National Missing Persons Week.

The Government is proud to recognise and support National Missing Persons Week and commends the Missing Persons Advocacy Network for its tireless work in raising awareness of missing persons in Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2862 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVIDSafe
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 23 August 2021 concerning Petition number: EN2865 regarding the right of Australians to keep their personal information private and not have it entered into a government app. I also acknowledge the request for the House of Representatives to withdraw the COVIDSafe app.
The COVIDSafe app remains an important element of the Australian Government's approach to managing the COVID-19 pandemic.

COVIDSafe was developed utilising a privacy-by-design approach, that would not track the location of app users, and these protections were enshrined in the Privacy Act 1988 to give Australians confidence that their private information is safe.

Use of the COVIDSafe app is completely voluntary. A person can use a pseudonym, rather than their actual name, when registering for the COVIDSafe app. The other personal information entered is the user's mobile telephone number, age (within a specified range) and postcode.
COVIDSafe uses secure encryption to further protect the user's personal information.

Once downloaded, a person may delete the COVIDSafe app from their phone at any time. Individuals do not have to consent to sharing their COVIDSafe app information if they test positive for COVID-19 and can request that their data be deleted from the National COVIDSafe Data Store at any time.
I trust this information is of use to the petitioners and I thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning Petition EN2925 to stop vaccine trials.

The Australian Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID-19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. The safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia. All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

This involves comprehensive review of clinical trial data, non-clinical and toxicological studies, chemistry, manufacturing, quality, risk management and other information by a large team of clinical and scientific experts. Advice is then sought from an independent expert committee before a regulatory decision is made.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data. No part of the process has been rushed and the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The urgency of the global pandemic means that researchers, agencies such as the World Health Organisation and governments all over the world are prioritising the development, assessment and rollout of COVID-19 vaccines.
There is a combination of reasons why safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines have been able to be designed, researched and made available sooner than previously seen. For example:
unprecedented levels of funding—the pandemic is a global priority and governments around the world are investing in research and manufacturing facilities

technology - the evolution of technology has allowed vaccines to be developed at a faster pace than in the past. New technologies have helped scientists understand the coronavirus and its make up much easier, which has allowed them to start working on vaccine design quicker
combined clinical trials - in response to the pandemic, some pharmaceutical companies have combined clinical trial phases 1 and 2

expedited review process by regulatory agencies—the TGA is engaging early with pharmaceutical companies about their vaccines and is accepting rolling data. This means that the TGA can accept, review and assess clinical trial data as it becomes available, rather than all at once at the end of the three clinical trial phases.

All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes including clinical trials. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

The TGA requires robust scientific data before supporting a vaccine candidate and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is found to be safe and effective, following its complete assessment of data.

The TGA undertook an independent and rigorous assessment of the available data for the Pfizer and Moderna mRNA COVID-19 vaccines. The data provided to the TGA was comprehensive and included pre-clinical and clinical studies, non-clinical and toxicology studies, chemistry, manufacturing, risk management and other information. All data was carefully reviewed by a large team ofTGA's technical and clinical experts before provisionally approving both vaccines.

Technology using Messenger RNA (mRNA) has been in development for decades, with clinical trials in humans being conducted as early as 2011. The COVID-19 pandemic provided funding and opportunity for researchers who have been studying and working with mRNA vaccines to produce safe and effective vaccines.

The Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines use a fragment of mRNA to instruct the body to generate immune response against COVID-19. One dose (0.3ml) of the Pfizer vaccine contains 30 micrograms of mRNA, and one dose (0.5ml) of the Moderna vaccine contains 100 micrograms of mRNA. More information concerning the ingredients of COVID-19 vaccines can be found in the Product Information, available at: www.tga.gov.au.

Based on the naturally occurring process for protein production in our body, mRNA for COVID-19 vaccines is synthetically designed and produced, containing only a short version of the viral mRNA that encodes for the spike protein. mRNA is fragile, which is why it is combined with lipids (fats) that protect it from being degraded until after it has been delivered to the cell. The mRNA enters the muscle cells which make the spike protein, displaying it so that it is recognised by our immune system. This allows the body's natural defences to develop immunity to the disease, so the body is able to rapidly create its own antibodies to prevent disease if it encounters the virus in the future. Once it has provided the instructions for the spike protein, the mRNA is broken down quickly by the body. It never enters the nucleus and cannot affect or combine with our DNA in any way to change our genetic code or the body's cells. Real world data collated and analysed as part of the global rollout have shown that the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are highly effective and safe vaccines.

The TGA is also part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development of COVID-19 vaccines. This information, together with the potential to use already established work-sharing arrangements and collaboration with other international regulators, is assisting the TGA to expedite the evaluation of any new vaccines without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality, and effectiveness.

The Government also continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine and treatment developers and manufacturers and continues to monitor ongoing clinical trials and review real world effectiveness of vaccine rollouts globally. There are over 400 trials for 140 vaccine candidates worldwide, including a number that are trialling the use of needle-free technology. These include nasal sprays, oral tablets, skin patches and jet injectors.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Foreign Investment
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence with respect to Petition EN2929 concerning foreign ownership of Australian land.

Australia's foreign investment framework is open and welcoming, as it needs to be for Australia to continue to attract the high inflows of foreign investment that it requires to supplement domestic savings and support Australia's economic development.

At the same time, the Government recognises that foreign investments must be in our national interest. If it is determined that a proposed foreign investment is contrary to the national interest, it will not be approved or conditions will be applied to safeguard the national interest.

Since taking office, the Government has strengthened the rules around foreign investors owning Australian land, including by lowering the agriculture screening thresholds; clarifying that foreign investors can only acquire agricultural land where Australian bidders have had an equal opportunity to participate in the sale process; and placing a cap on foreign ownership in new residential developments.

The Government has also enacted comprehensive reforms to the foreign investment framework which came into effect from 1 January 2021. These reforms update the framework in three broad ways: address national security risks; strengthen the compliance regime foreign investors are subject to and the enforcement powers available to the Treasurer; and streamline investment in non-sensitive businesses.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Foreign Investment
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence with respect to Petition EN2972 concerning foreign owned real estate in Australia.

Australia's foreign investment framework is open and welcoming, as it needs to be for Australia to continue to attract the high inflows of foreign investment that it requires to supplement domestic savings and support Australia's economic development.

At the same time, the Government recognises that foreign investments must be in our national interest. If it is determined that a proposed foreign investment is contrary to the national interest, it will not be approved or conditions will be applied to safeguard the national interest.

Since taking office, the Government has strengthened the rules around foreign investors owning Australian housing, including by introducing an annual charge on foreign owners who buy residential property and leave it vacant; placing a cap on foreign ownership in new developments; and tightening the foreign investor tax integrity rules to reduce avoidance of capital gains tax.

The Government's policy is to channel foreign investment into new dwellings, as this increases the total dwelling stock in which Australians can live, creates additional jobs in the construction industry and supports economic growth.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Medical Workforce
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN2977 presented to the House of Representatives on the same date concerning the Distribution Priority Area (DPA) status of the Hunter Region.

The Australian Government is strongly committed to improving the access, quality and sustainability of health services for all Australians, particularly in regional, rural and remote Australia. The primary issue of the health workforce in Australia is one of equitable distribution of qualified professionals rather than supply, with data showing that over the past decade the rate of increase in GP numbers has been two and a half times greater than that of the general population.

The Government uses the DPA classification system to identify the distribution challenges of the medical workforce. It is used to identify the level of services provided to a population and is used to assess whether there is a service shortfall. It is intended to support practices by offering access to a broader recruitment pool of doctors, particularly targeting doctors to rural areas through location restrictions on their practice, including international medical graduates under s19AB of the Health Insurance Act 1973 and the Bonded Medical Program. It does not guarantee a doctor, nor does it prevent recruitment of Australian trained doctors.

The Hunter region is classified as non-DPA. This means at the time of this assessment the GP catchment is deemed to have a higher level of medical service provision compared to the relevant benchmark/s. This can change as the circumstances in a particular location change - such as a demographic shift or reduction/improvement in service access for the population.

I acknowledge that practices in non-DPA locations can also face recruitment challenges, irrespective of access to the wider pool of doctors that DPA status provides. This may be due to a wide range of factors. As well intentioned as the current DPA assessment process is, the Government is concerned that it is not sufficiently contemporaneous or agile in responding to current GP services needs of some communities. For this reason, my Department is currently facilitating a review of the methodology underpinning the DPA for GPs classification system.

The review will be ambitious in its intent, open to innovative thinking and broadly consultative to ensure that concerns are addressed. It is expected that a final report will be presented towards the end of 2021. Please be assured that the Government will move quickly to address any recommendations.

Additionally, noting the outcome of the 2021 annual DPA update and the consequences of the DPA status on areas facing GP recruitment and retention challenges, the Government has also established an exceptional circumstances assessment framework to provide for a more fulsome, independent, and real time review of DPA status. Applications by doctors or others with GP access concerns, that have also worked with their local Rural Workforce Agency (RWA) will be considered. The outcome of the assessment will also be published online to ensure full transparency. Further information on how the process will work is enclosed.

The Government funds a network of seven RWAs, one in each state and the Northern Territory, to provide assistance to communities that experience difficulties attracting and retaining health professionals into regional, rural and remote areas. The RWA in New South Wales (NSW) is the Rural Doctors Network (RDN). The NSW RDN can be contacted on (02) 4924 8000, or via email: enquiries@nswrdn.com.au.

The Government also provides funding to Primary Health Networks (PHN) who work closely with GPs and other health professionals to build health workforce capacity and support general practice. The Hunter region is covered by the Hunter New England and Central Coast PHN. Practices in the Hunter region may wish to seek information from the PHN on whether its programs may be able to assist the local situation. For more information please visit its website at: www.thephn.com.au or by phoning 1300 859 028.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Encl (1)
cc: The Hon Dr David Gillespie, Minister for Regional Health

span.span: Exceptional circumstances assessments for regions with GP services access concerns

p.span: The Australian Government uses the Distribution Priority Area (DPA) indicator to identify distribution challenges in Australia's medical workforce. DPA is calculated by comparing the actual level of GP services provided to a GP catchment with the level of services the same community should receive if they were receiving a benchmark level of GP Services.

DPA is an impartial mechanism which relies on the most recently available Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) demographic data (including age, gender and socio-economic status) as well as Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) billing data to assess levels of medical service provision throughout Australia. The DPA is reviewed and updated annually to reflect the latest available data.
The Government also recognises that sometimes, an area can face pressures that are not picked up in the DPA assessment.

Additional factors are now able to be considered alongside an area's non-DPA status. This assessment may see an area become, for that year, DPA to support recruitment of a broader pool of doctors into the area. This should address any GP services shortfall arising from those additional factors.
The Distribution Working Group (DWG) will assess applications seeking a change to an area's non-DPA status.
Anyone can apply for an assessment. Applicants will need to work with the Rural Workforce Agency (RWA) and the Department of Health to gather the information to be assessed.
The DWG will review the non-DPA status of an area based on the following criteria:
1) Support of the local Rural Health Workforce Agency (RWA)

The application for exceptional circumstances must have the support and engagement of the RWA in their state/territory. The area must demonstrate the RWA is working with them to address workforce concerns and that steps have been or are being taken to implement RWA advice or support actions.
2) Changes to health services, workforce or health system

The area can demonstrate an unexpected large change to the health workforce resulting in a substantial drop in health services to the community that is not recognised in the last DPA update. This may include changes in services arrangements, for example doctor retirements (without replacement), hospital closures or an unexpected sharp increase in population.
3) Patient demographics or changes

The patient cohort is within a demographic that is underserviced, or requires a specialised nature of service. Socio-economic status, proportion of ageing, or Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the area are all able to be considered.
4) Absence of services

The area can demonstrate difficulties in recruiting or retaining medical practitioners at a scale that is measurably different to similar communities and would warrant discretion being applied within health workforce programs.
How requests for review are considered
The request for review must have the support and involvement of the Rural Workforce Agency (RWA) in the state or territory.
Claims against the Criteria should be sent to rural.distribution@health.gov.au along with supporting documentation from the RWA, other supporting documentation or letters of support.
Requests will be assessed by the DWG within 3 weeks of submission.
The Department of Health will advise of the outcome within 2 weeks of the DWG decision date.
DWG outcomes will also be published online to ensure transparency.
COVID-19: Domestic Travel
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN2979, domestic and international vaccine passports.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective means of preventing the spread and development of diseases such as COVID-19 in the community, and everyone's decision to receive a COVID-19 vaccination is acknowledged and appreciated.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public health orders which require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public health orders can be found on the relevant state or territory government websites.

Australians can already provide voluntary proof of vaccination by accessing their immunisation history statement through Medicare Online, via the Express Plus Medicare mobile app or via their My Health Record. People can seek a hard copy of their immunisation history statement by contacting the Australian Immunisation Register enquiries line, or through their doctor or immunisation provider.

The Government, through Services Australia and my Department, has also developed a safe and secure COVID-19 Digital Certificate which may help Australians provide proof of vaccination if it required. The certificate is already available through the Medicare Express app for those who wish to use it.

As part of our four-phase National Plan to Transition Australia's National COVID Response, the Commonwealth will introduce an International COVID-19 Vaccine Certificate for outbound travellers to present at foreign borders and at the Australian border. This certificate has been designed to meet the new standards specified by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and endorsed by the World Health Organization.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Statistics
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN2991 requesting a full history of testing cycle rates in Australia be made publicly available with regard to the use of polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing.

The Australian Government is continuing to take a strong and decisive approach to responding to COVID-19, based on the latest medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee, and its expert standing committees, including the Public Health Laboratory Network (PHLN), and remains vigilant about the evolution of the pandemic.

Australia is also fortunate to be supported by an expert and extensive network of public and private laboratories with the capability, capacity, and appropriate accreditation to detect SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19). The ability of this sector to scale-up testing capacity has been essential to Australia's success in flattening the curve and avoiding the devastating infection rates seen in other countries.

In Australia, nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) using PCR on a respiratory sample collected by a throat and bilateral deep nasal (or nasopharyngeal) swab is the gold standard test for the acute diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection. This test method is very sensitive and detects nucleic acid sequences specific to the virus. PCR testing has been comprehensively validated and continues to be monitored by pathology laboratories both locally and internationally to ensure a high testing and performance standard is met.

During the testing process, the PCR amplifies (makes many copies of) a highly specific target region of the SARS-CoV-2 genome so that it can be detected. Each amplification reaction is known as a cycle. The cycle threshold (Ct) value of a reaction is the cycle number when the fluorescence of a PCR product can be detected above the background signal. Each PCR assay may have a different Ct value that is used for detecting SARS-CoV-2.

Ct values for one in vitro diagnostic (IVD) device should not be compared with Ct values from other platforms. Ct values are IVD device dependant. This means there is no 'set' Ct value to aim for across all platforms. There are also nucleic acid amplification devices used for the diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection which do not record a Ct value. The Ct value is not the only criterion used to evaluate a result. The 'melt curve' is often part of a result assessment. It is for this reason that PCR test results must be interpreted by a suitably qualified pathologist or medical laboratory scientist.

Commercial IVD devices are subject to Therapeutic Goods Administration regulations and require that pathologists and medical laboratory scientists to follow the manufacturer's instructions for use. For in-house assays, the parameters for determining a result have been determined by the laboratory through the assay development and evaluation process.

In Australia, all properly accredited pathology providers offering testing to detect SARS-CoV-2 operate in accordance with the requirements established by the National Pathology Accreditation Advisory Council (NPAAC) and undergo accreditation by assessment by the National Association of Testing Authorities, Australia in conjunction with the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia which assess to the NPAAC requirements and use the international standard ISO 1589 as an assessment guide.

The combined SARS-CoV-2 PCR testing experience in Australia is that the false positive rate is extremely low. However, it is important to note that no test has 100 per cent sensitivity or specificity in all clinical circumstances. PCR testing may not always detect the virus when it is present in low levels. For example, after initial infection with SARS-CoV-2, it takes a number of days for viral replication to produce enough genetic material to be detected by PCR. This occurs roughly two to three days before symptoms become apparent. Testing during the incubation period may return a negative result, even when an individual is infected with SARS-CoV-2.

Therefore, it is important that all testing for SARS-CoV-2 is conducted in line with the Communicable Diseases Network Australia (CDNA) COVID-19 Series of National Guidelines for Public Health Units. The CDNA Guidance can·be found at:
www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cdna-song-novel-coronavirus.htm.

Further information on interpreting SARS-CoV-2 NAAT results, including PCR, can be found in the PHLN guidance on nucleic acid test result interpretation for SARS-CoV-2 on my Department's website. The guidance can be found at:
www.health.gov.au/resources/publications/phln-guidance-on-nucleic-acid-test-result-interpretation-for-sars-cov-2.

As the pandemic situation continues to evolve and new evidence emerges, the Australian Government will continue to review its response strategies and provide Australians with the most up-to-date information and advice. A visit to the Department's website at: www.health.gov.au will keep you well-informed about Australia's health response.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition EN2994 - Mixing AstraZeneca and Pfizer.
Based on current evidence, the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) recommends using the same COVID-19 vaccine for the two doses of the primary course.
While there is emerging data concerning mixed dose schedules, larger studies and longer term follow up are required to confirm safety of this approach.

ATAGI has provided clinical advice for the circumstances under which a mixed schedule can be used. These circumstances include a serious adverse event following the first dose of a COVID-19 vaccine, people with specific precautionary conditions and people who may have received an incomplete course of a COVID-19 vaccine brand not available in Australia.
Emerging data demonstrates that mixed schedules do produce an immune response and have an acceptable safety profile.
ATAGI continue to monitor and review the evidence for mixed COVID-19 vaccine schedules and provide updated recommendations to Government as appropriate.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at:
www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
E-Cigarettes
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning Petition EN3016 regarding legalising the use of nicotine vaping solution in Australia.

The use of nicotine vaping products (such as nicotine e-cigarettes, nicotine pods and liquid nicotine) is not banned. If prescribed by a doctor, it is legal to use nicotine vaping products. Indeed, the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) scheduling delegate's decision, which is independent of the Australian Government, brings, from 1 October 2021, the importation rules into line with state and territory regulations which were already unlawfully sold domestically without a prescription.

Tobacco use remains one of the leading causes of preventable death and disability among Australians. The clear, consistent evidence that nicotine vaping products are a gateway to cigarette smoking for young people supports the TGA's decision as an appropriate measure to protect children and others from unrestricted access to nicotine vaping products. This is particularly pertinent in light of the rapid growth in youth uptake in vaping overseas and already seen emerging in Australia.
